Hepatitis.Prevention: Vaccination (for viral hepatitis), avoiding excessive alcohol

Hepatitis A.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dark urine, jaundice, fever, abdominal pain
Hepatitis A.Causes: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with Hepatovirus A infected feces
Hepatitis A.Prevention: Hepatitis A vaccine, hand washing, properly cooking food

Hepatitis B.Symptoms: None, yellowish skin, tiredness, dark urine, abdominal pain
Hepatitis B.Usual onset: Symptoms may take up to 6 months to appear
Hepatitis B.Causes: Hepatitis B virus spread by some body fluids
Hepatitis B.Risk factors: Intravenous drug use, sexual intercourse, dialysis, living with an infected person

Hepatitis C.Complications: Liver failure, liver cancer, esophageal and gastric varices
Hepatitis C.Causes: Hepatitis C virus usually spread by blood-to-blood contact
Hepatitis C.Diagnostic method: Blood testing for antibodies or viral RNA

Herpes Simplex.Symptoms: Blisters that break open and form small ulcers, fever, swollen lymph nodes
Herpes Simplex.Causes: Herpes simplex virus spread by direct contact
Herpes Simplex.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, PCR,  viral culture

High risk pregnancy.Risk factors: High blood pressure, diabetes, heart disease, renal disease, autoimmune disease, fetal growth restriction, multiple gestations, congenital fetal abnormalities

Human papillomavirus.Complications: Cancer of the cervix, vulva, vagina, penis, anus, mouth, tonsils, or throat
Human papillomavirus.Causes: Human papillomavirus spread by direct contact
Human papillomavirus.Frequency: Most people are infected at some point in time

Hypermetropia.Symptoms: Near blur, Distance and near blur, Asthenopia
Hypermetropia.Complications: Accommodative dysfunction, binocular dysfunction, amblyopia, strabismus
Hypermetropia.Causes: Axial length of eyeball is too short, lens or cornea is flatter than normal, aphakia
Hypermetropia.Differential diagnosis: Amblyopia, retrobulbar optic neuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa sine pigmento
Hypermetropia.Treatment: Eyeglasses, contact lenses, refractive surgeries, IOL implantation

Hyperthyroidism.Symptoms: Irritability, muscle weakness, sleeping problems, fast heartbeat, heat intolerance, diarrhea, enlargement of the thyroid, weight loss
Hyperthyroidism.Causes: Graves' disease, multinodular goiter, toxic adenoma, inflammation of the thyroid, eating too much iodine, too much synthetic thyroid hormone
Hyperthyroidism.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and confirmed by blood tests

Hypothyroid.Symptoms: Poor ability to tolerate cold, feeling tired, constipation, weight gain, depression, anxiety, irritability
Hypothyroid.Complications: During pregnancy can result in cretinism in the baby
Hypothyroid.Differential diagnosis: Depression, dementia, heart failure, chronic fatigue syndrome

Impetigo.Causes: Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes which spreads by direct contact
Impetigo.Risk factors: Day care, crowding, poor nutrition, diabetes mellitus, contact sports, breaks in the skin
Impetigo.Prevention: Hand washing, avoiding infected people, cleaning injuries

Inflammatory Bowel Disease.Differential diagnosis: Gastroenteritis, irritable bowel syndrome, celiac disease

Influenza.Symptoms: Fever, runny nose, sore throat, muscle pain, headache, coughing, fatigue

Insomnia.Symptoms: Trouble sleeping, daytime sleepiness, low energy, irritability, depressed mood
Insomnia.Causes: Unknown, psychological stress, chronic pain, heart failure, hyperthyroidism, heartburn, restless leg syndrome, others
Insomnia.Differential diagnosis: Delayed sleep phase disorder, restless leg syndrome, sleep apnea, psychiatric disorder
Insomnia.Treatment: Sleep hygiene, cognitive behavioral therapy, sleeping pills

Interstitial cystitis.Other names: Bladder pain syndrome (BPS), painful bladder syndrome (PBS), IC/BPS, IC/PBS, UCPPS
Interstitial cystitis.Symptoms: Chronic pain of the bladder, feeling the need to urinate right away, needing to urinate often, pain with sex
Interstitial cystitis.Diagnostic method: Based on the symptoms after ruling out other conditions
Interstitial cystitis.Differential diagnosis: Urinary tract infection, overactive bladder, sexually transmitted infections, endometriosis, bladder cancer, prostatitis

Iritis.Symptoms: Headaches, red eyes, blurred vision, photophobia, burning and redness of the eye
Iritis.Causes: Behçet disease, Crohn's disease, Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, HLA-B27 related uveitis, Juvenile idiopathic arthritis, Sarcoidosis, Spondyloarthritis, Sympathetic ophthalmia, Tubulointerstitial nephritis and uveitis syndrome, brucellosis, herpesviruses, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, presumed ocular histoplasmosis syndrome, syphilis, toxocariasis, toxoplasmic chorioretinitis, tuberculosis, Zika fever

Iron Deficiency Anemia.Symptoms: Feeling tired, weakness, dizziness, headache, lightheadedness, breathlessness, decreased ability to concentrate, confusion, pallor
Iron Deficiency Anemia.Medication: Iron supplements, vitamin C, blood transfusions

Irritable bowel syndrome.Other names: Spastic colon, nervous colon, mucous colitis, spastic bowel
Irritable bowel syndrome.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, exclusion of other diseases
Irritable bowel syndrome.Differential diagnosis: Celiac disease, giardiasis, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, microscopic colitis, inflammatory bowel disease, bile acid malabsorption, colon cancer
Irritable bowel syndrome.Treatment: Symptomatic (dietary changes, medication, human milk oligosaccharides, probiotics, counseling)

Japanese Encephalitis.Prevention: Japanese encephalitis vaccine, avoiding mosquito bites
Japanese Encephalitis.Prognosis: Permanent neurological problems occur in up to half of survivors

Jaundice.Symptoms: Yellowish coloration of skin and whites of the eyes, itchiness
Jaundice.Risk factors: Pancreatic cancer, Pancreatitis, Liver disease, Certain infections

Kala-azar/ Leishmaniasis.Symptoms: Skin ulcers, fever, low red blood cells, enlarged liver

Kaposi\u2019s Sarcoma.Differential diagnosis: Blue rubber bleb nevus syndrome, pyogenic granuloma, melanocytic nevi, melanoma
Kaposi\u2019s Sarcoma.Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, biologic therapy

Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca (Dry eye synd.Other names: Dry eye, keratoconjunctivitis sicca, dry eye disease (DED), keratitis sicca
Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca (Dry eye synd.Symptoms: Dry eyes, irritation, redness, discharge, blurred vision
Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca (Dry eye synd.Causes: Contact lenses, meibomian gland dysfunction, pregnancy, Sjögren syndrome, vitamin A deficiency, LASIK surgery, antihistamines, hormone replacement therapy, antidepressants
Keratoconjunctivitis Sicca (Dry eye synd.Treatment: Artificial tears, wrap around glasses, changing certain medications

Kuru.Symptoms: Body tremors, random outbursts of laughter, gradual loss of coordination
Kuru.Complications: Infection and pneumonia during the terminal stage.
Kuru.Usual onset: Often takes years or even decades for symptoms to appear after exposure
Kuru.Duration: 11–14 month life expectancy after onset of symptoms

Laryngitis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, examination via laryngoscopy if concerns

Lead poisoning.Other names: Plumbism, colica pictorum, saturnism, Devon colic, painter's colic
Lead poisoning.Symptoms: Intellectual disability, abdominal pain, constipation, headaches, irritability, memory problems, inability to have children, tingling in the hands and feet
Lead poisoning.Causes: Exposure to lead via contaminated air, water, dust, food, consumer products
Lead poisoning.Differential diagnosis: Iron deficiency anemia, malabsorption, anxiety disorder, polyneuropathy
Lead poisoning.Prevention: Removing lead from the home, improved monitoring and education in the workplace, laws that ban lead in products

Legionellosis.Symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath, fever, muscle pains, headaches
Legionellosis.Causes: Bacteria of the Legionella type (spread by contaminated mist)
Legionellosis.Risk factors: Older age, history of smoking, chronic lung disease, poor immune function

Leprosy.Risk factors: Close contact with a case of leprosy, living in poverty

Leptospirosis.Other names: Rat fever, field fever, rat catcher's yellows, pretibial fever
Leptospirosis.Complications: Bleeding from the lungs, meningitis, kidney failure
Leptospirosis.Risk factors: Exposure to infected animals or contaminated water
Leptospirosis.Diagnostic method: Testing blood for antibodies against the bacterium or its DNA
Leptospirosis.Prevention: Personal protective equipment, hygiene measures, doxycycline

Leukemia.Symptoms: Bleeding, bruising, fatigue, fever, increased risk of infections
Leukemia.Usual onset: All ages, most common in 60s and 70s. It is the most common malignant cancer in children, but the cure rates are also higher for them.
Leukemia.Risk factors: Smoking, stress, family history, ionizing radiation, some chemicals, prior chemotherapy, Down syndrome.
Leukemia.Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapy, bone marrow transplant, supportive care

Lung cancer.Symptoms: Coughing (including coughing up blood), weight loss, shortness of breath, chest pains
Lung cancer.Types: Small-cell lung carcinoma (SCLC), non-small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC)
Lung cancer.Prevention: Not smoking, avoiding radon gas, asbestos, second-hand smoke, or other forms of air pollution exposure.
Lung cancer.Prognosis: Five-year survival rate: 10 to 20% (most countries), 33% (Japan), 27% (Israel), 25% (Republic of Korea)

Lyme disease.Symptoms: Expanding area of redness at the site of a tick bite, fever, headache, tiredness
Lyme disease.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, tick exposure, blood tests
Lyme disease.Prevention: Prevention of tick bites (clothing the limbs, DEET), doxycycline

Lymphoma.Symptoms: Enlarged lymph nodes, fever, sweats, unintended weight loss, itching, feeling tired
Lymphoma.Risk factors: Epstein–Barr virus, autoimmune diseases, HIV/AIDS, tobacco smoking
Lymphoma.Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, proton therapy, targeted therapy, surgery

Mad cow disease.Symptoms: Abnormal behavior, trouble walking, weight loss, inability to move
Mad cow disease.Complications: variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (if BSE-infected beef is eaten by humans)
Mad cow disease.Risk factors: Feeding contaminated meat and bone meal to cattle
Mad cow disease.Diagnostic method: Suspected based on symptoms, confirmed by examination of the brain
Mad cow disease.Prevention: Not allowing sick or older animals to enter the food supply, disallowing certain products in animal food

Malaria.Diagnostic method: Examination of the blood, antigen detection tests
Malaria.Prevention: Mosquito nets, insect repellent, mosquito control, medications

Marburg fever.Risk factors: Direct contact with bodily fluids of individuals infected with the virus
Marburg fever.Treatment: There is no treatment, only immediate supportive care

Mastitis.Symptoms: Localized breast pain and redness, fever
Mastitis.Differential diagnosis: Plugged milk duct, breast engorgement, breast cancer (rare)

Measles.Other names: Morbilli, rubeola, red measles, English measles
Measles.Symptoms: Fever, cough, runny nose, inflamed eyes, rash
Measles.Complications: Pneumonia, seizures, encephalitis, subacute sclerosing panencephalitis, immunosuppression, hearing loss, blindness

Melanoma.Symptoms: Mole that is increasing in size, has irregular edges, change in color, itchiness, or skin breakdown.
Melanoma.Risk factors: Family history, many moles, poor immune function
Melanoma.Differential diagnosis: Seborrheic keratosis, lentigo, blue nevus, dermatofibroma

Migraine.Symptoms: Headaches, nausea, sensitivity to light, sensitivity to sound, sensitivity to smell
Migraine.Differential diagnosis: Subarachnoid hemorrhage, venous thrombosis, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, brain tumor, tension headache, sinusitis, cluster headache

Mononucleosis.Other names: Glandular fever, Pfeiffer's disease, Filatov's disease, kissing disease
Mononucleosis.Symptoms: Fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes in the neck, tiredness
Mononucleosis.Complications: Swelling of the liver or spleen
Mononucleosis.Causes: Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) usually spread via saliva
Mononucleosis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and blood tests
Mononucleosis.Treatment: Drinking enough fluids, getting sufficient rest, pain medications such as paracetamol (acetaminophen) and ibuprofen

Mouth Breathing.Symptoms: Snoring, dry mouth, hoarse voice, bad breath, fatigue
Mouth Breathing.Treatment: Treatment of the underlying cause of nasal congestion if present, building a habit to breathe through the nose

Multiple myeloma.Other names: Plasma cell myeloma, myelomatosis, Kahler's disease, myeloma
Multiple myeloma.Complications: Amyloidosis, kidney problems, bone fractures, hyperviscosity syndrome,  infections, anemia: 653
Multiple myeloma.Diagnostic method: Blood or urine tests, bone marrow biopsy, medical imaging
Multiple myeloma.Treatment: Steroids, chemotherapy, thalidomide, stem cell transplant, bisphosphonates, radiation therapy
Multiple myeloma.Prognosis: Five-year survival rate 54% / life expectancy 6 years (USA)

Multiple sclerosis.Symptoms:
Bladder overactivity, bowel (constipation, bowel incontinence), cognition problems (anxiety, depression, limited critical thinking, learning, and planning), fatigue, hearing impairment or loss, mobility problems (dizziness – vertigo, lightheadedness, coordination issues, tremor), muscle problems (spasms, stiffness, and/or weakness), numbness and/or tingling, pain (stabbing pains in the face, feeling of burning, pins and needles, hugging or squeezing in the trunk and limbs), sexual problems (erectile dysfunction, ejaculation issues, decrease in vaginal lubrication and sensation), speech and/or swallowing difficulties, sensation problems, vision problems (double vision, blindness in one eye) 
Symptoms may not present all at once, may come and go, and range from mild to severe.
Multiple sclerosis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and medical tests

Mumps.Symptoms: Parotitis and non-specific symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, muscle pain, and loss of appetite
Mumps.Complications: Deafness, inflammatory conditions such as orchitis, oophoritis, and pancreatitis, and rarely sterility
Mumps.Diagnostic method: Antibody testing, viral cultures, and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction
Mumps.Prognosis: Usually excellent; case fatality rate of 1.6–3.8 people per 10,000
Mumps.Frequency: Most common in childhood and in countries that do not vaccinate

Muscular dystrophy.Symptoms: Increasing weakening, breakdown of skeletal muscles, trouble walking
Muscular dystrophy.Types: > 30, including Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Becker muscular dystrophy, facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy, limb–girdle muscular dystrophy, myotonic dystrophy
Muscular dystrophy.Causes: Genetic (X-linked recessive, autosomal recessive, or autosomal dominant)
Muscular dystrophy.Treatment: Pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, braces, corrective surgery, assisted ventilation

Myasthenia gravis.Symptoms: Varying degrees muscle weakness, double vision, drooping eyelids, trouble talking, trouble walking
Myasthenia gravis.Diagnostic method: Blood tests for specific antibodies, edrophonium test, nerve conduction studies
Myasthenia gravis.Differential diagnosis: Guillain–Barré syndrome, botulism, organophosphate poisoning, brainstem stroke
Myasthenia gravis.Treatment: Medications, surgical removal of the thymus, plasmapheresis

Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack).Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, feeling faint, cold sweat, feeling tired; arm, neck, back, jaw, or stomach pain
Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack).Complications: Heart failure, irregular heartbeat, cardiogenic shock, cardiac arrest
Myocardial Infarction (Heart Attack).Risk factors: High blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol

Myopia.Symptoms: Distant objects appear blurry, close objects appear normal, headaches, eye strain
Myopia.Causes: Combination of genetic and environmental factors
Myopia.Risk factors: Near work, greater time spent indoors, family history

Narcolepsy.Symptoms: Excessive daytime sleepiness, involuntary sleep episodes, sudden loss of muscle strength, hallucinations
Narcolepsy.Diagnostic method: Based on the symptoms and sleep studies
Narcolepsy.Differential diagnosis: Sleep apnea, major depressive disorder, anemia, heart failure, drinking alcohol, not getting enough sleep

Nasal Polyps.Symptoms: Trouble breathing through the nose, loss of smell, decreased taste, post nasal drip, runny nose
Nasal Polyps.Risk factors: Allergies, cystic fibrosis, aspirin sensitivity, certain infections
Nasal Polyps.Diagnostic method: Looking up the nose, CT scan

Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hy.Symptoms: Nausea and vomiting such that weight loss and dehydration occur
Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hy.Duration: Often gets better but may last entire pregnancy
Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hy.Risk factors: First pregnancy, multiple pregnancy, obesity, prior or family history of hyperemesis gravidarum, trophoblastic disorder, history of an eating disorder
Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hy.Differential diagnosis: Urinary tract infection, high thyroid levels
Nausea and Vomiting of Pregnancy and Hy.Treatment: Drinking fluids, bland diet, intravenous fluids

Necrotizing Fasciitis.Other names: Flesh-eating bacteria, flesh-eating bacteria syndrome, necrotizing soft tissue infection (NSTI), fasciitis necroticans
Necrotizing Fasciitis.Symptoms: Severe pain, fever, purple colored skin in the affected area
Necrotizing Fasciitis.Causes: Multiple types of bacteria, occasional fungus
Necrotizing Fasciitis.Risk factors: Poor immune function such as from diabetes or cancer, obesity, alcoholism, intravenous drug use, peripheral artery disease
Necrotizing Fasciitis.Treatment: Surgery to remove the infected tissue, intravenous antibiotics

Nipah virus infection.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, confirmed by laboratory testing
Nipah virus infection.Prevention: Avoiding exposure to bats and to sick pigs and people.

Obesity.Complications: Cardiovascular diseases, type 2 diabetes, obstructive sleep apnea, certain types of cancer, osteoarthritis, depression
Obesity.Causes: Excessive food, lack of exercise, genetics

Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.Symptoms: Feel the need to check things repeatedly, perform certain routines repeatedly, have certain thoughts repeatedly
Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.Differential diagnosis: Anxiety disorder, major depressive disorder, eating disorders, obsessive–compulsive personality disorder
Obsessive Compulsive Disorder.Treatment: Counseling, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, clomipramine

Oral Cancer.Other names: Cancer of the lip, oral cavity and pharynx, mouth cancer, cancer or the lips, oral cavity and pharynx
Oral Cancer.Specialty: Oncology, oral and maxillofacial surgery, ENT surgery
Oral Cancer.Symptoms: Persistent rough white or red patch in the mouth lasting longer than 2 weeks, ulceration, lumps/bumps in the neck, pain, loose teeth, difficulty swallowing
Oral Cancer.Risk factors: Smoking, alcohol, HPV infection, sun exposure, chewing tobacco
Oral Cancer.Differential diagnosis: Non-squamous cell carcinoma oral cancer, salivary gland tumors, benign mucosal disease

Osteoarthritis.Other names: Degenerative arthritis, degenerative joint disease, osteoarthrosis
Osteoarthritis.Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, joint swelling, decreased range of motion
Osteoarthritis.Causes: Connective tissue disease, previous joint injury, abnormal joint or limb development, inherited factors
Osteoarthritis.Risk factors: Overweight, legs of different lengths, job with high levels of joint stress
Osteoarthritis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, supported by other testing
Osteoarthritis.Treatment: Exercise, efforts to decrease joint stress, support groups, pain medications, joint replacement

Osteomyelitis.Symptoms: Pain in a specific bone, overlying redness, fever, weakness
Osteomyelitis.Risk factors: Diabetes, intravenous drug use, prior removal of the spleen, trauma to the area
Osteomyelitis.Diagnostic method: Blood tests, medical imaging, bone biopsy
Osteomyelitis.Differential diagnosis: Charcot's joint, rheumatoid arthritis, infectious arthritis, giant cell tumor, cellulitis
Osteomyelitis.Prognosis: Low risk of death with treatment

Osteoporosis.Symptoms: Increased risk of a broken bone
Osteoporosis.Risk factors: Alcoholism, anorexia, European or Asian ethnicity, hyperthyroidism, gastrointestinal diseases, surgical removal of the ovaries, kidney disease, smoking, certain medications
Osteoporosis.Treatment: Good diet, exercise, fall prevention, stopping smoking

Paratyphoid fever.Causes: Salmonella enterica spread by food or water contaminated with feces
Paratyphoid fever.Diagnostic method: Culturing the bacteria or detecting its DNA in the blood, stool, or bone marrow

Parkinson's Disease.Other names: Parkinson disease, idiopathic or primary parkinsonism, hypokinetic rigid syndrome, paralysis agitans, shaking palsy
Parkinson's Disease.Symptoms: Tremor, rigidity, slowness of movement, difficulty walking
Parkinson's Disease.Differential diagnosis: Dementia with Lewy bodies, progressive supranuclear palsy, essential tremor, antipsychotic use

Pelvic inflammatory disease.Symptoms: Lower abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, fever, burning with urination, pain with sex, irregular menstruation
Pelvic inflammatory disease.Complications: Infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain, cancer
Pelvic inflammatory disease.Causes: Bacteria that spread from the vagina and cervix
Pelvic inflammatory disease.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, ultrasound, laparoscopic surgery
Pelvic inflammatory disease.Prevention: Not having sex, having few sexual partners, using condoms

Pericarditis.Symptoms: Sharp chest pain, better sitting up and worse with lying down, fever
Pericarditis.Causes: Viral infection, tuberculosis, uremic pericarditis, following a heart attack, cancer, autoimmune disorders, chest trauma
Pericarditis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, electrocardiogram, fluid around the heart

Peritonitis.Symptoms: Severe pain, swelling of the abdomen, fever
Peritonitis.Complications: Sepsis (sepsis is likely if not quickly treated), shock, acute respiratory distress syndrome
Peritonitis.Causes: Perforation of the intestinal tract, pancreatitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, cirrhosis, ruptured appendix
Peritonitis.Treatment: Antibiotics, intravenous fluids, pain medication, surgery

Pneumonia.Symptoms: Cough, difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, fever
Pneumonia.Risk factors: Cystic fibrosis, COPD, sickle cell disease, asthma, diabetes, heart failure, history of smoking, older age
Pneumonia.Differential diagnosis: COPD, asthma, pulmonary edema, pulmonary embolism

Poliomyelitis.Symptoms: Muscle weakness resulting in an inability to move
Poliomyelitis.Diagnostic method: Finding the virus in the feces or antibodies in the blood

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).Symptoms: Irregular menstrual periods, heavy periods, excess hair, acne, pelvic pain, difficulty getting pregnant, patches of thick, darker, velvety skin
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).Complications: Type 2 diabetes, obesity, obstructive sleep apnea, heart disease, mood disorders, endometrial cancer
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).Risk factors: Obesity, not enough exercise, family history
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).Diagnostic method: Based on anovulation, high androgen levels, ovarian cysts
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).Differential diagnosis: Adrenal hyperplasia, hypothyroidism, high blood levels of prolactin
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).Frequency: 2% to 20% of women of childbearing age[13]

Porphyria.Symptoms: Depending on subtype—abdominal pain, chest pain, vomiting, confusion, constipation, fever, seizures, blisters with sunlight
Porphyria.Usual onset: Recurrent attacks that last days to weeks
Porphyria.Diagnostic method: Blood, urine, and stool tests, genetic testing

Post-herpetic neuralgia.Symptoms: burning or stabbing pain, pain doesn't end after the shingles subsides.

Postpartum depression/ Perinatal depress.Symptoms: Extreme sadness, low energy, anxiety, changes in sleeping or eating patterns, crying episodes, irritability
Postpartum depression/ Perinatal depress.Usual onset: A week to a month after childbirth
Postpartum depression/ Perinatal depress.Risk factors: Prior postpartum depression, bipolar disorder, family history of depression, psychological stress, complications of childbirth, lack of support, drug use disorder

Preeclampsia.Symptoms: High blood pressure, protein in the urine
Preeclampsia.Complications: Red blood cell breakdown, low blood platelet count, impaired liver function, kidney problems, swelling, shortness of breath due to fluid in the lungs, eclampsia
Preeclampsia.Risk factors: Obesity, prior hypertension, older age, diabetes mellitus
Preeclampsia.Diagnostic method: BP > 140 mmHg systolic or 90 mmHg diastolic at two separate times
Preeclampsia.Prevention: Aspirin, calcium supplementation, treatment of prior hypertension

Premenstrual syndrome.Symptoms: Acne, tender breasts, abdominal bloating, feeling tired, mood changes
Premenstrual syndrome.Medication: Calcium and vitamin D supplementation, NSAIDs, birth control pills

Presbyopia.Symptoms: Difficulty reading small print, having to hold reading material farther away, headaches, eyestrain
Presbyopia.Usual onset: Progressively worsening in those over 40 years old
Presbyopia.Causes: Aging-related hardening of the lens of the eye

Preterm birth.Symptoms: Birth of a baby at younger than 37 weeks' gestational age
Preterm birth.Complications: Cerebral palsy, delays in development, hearing problems, sight problems
Preterm birth.Risk factors: Diabetes, high blood pressure, Multiple gestation, obesity or underweight, a number of vaginal infections, celiac disease, tobacco smoking, psychological stress
Preterm birth.Treatment: Corticosteroids, keeping the baby warm through skin-to-skin contact, supporting breastfeeding, treating infections, supporting breathing

Progeria.Other names: Hutchinson–Gilford progeria syndrome (HGPS), progeria syndrome, Joseph Syndrome
Progeria.Symptoms: Growth delay, short height, small face, hair loss
Progeria.Differential diagnosis: Hallermann–Streiff syndrome, Gottron's syndrome, Wiedemann–Rautenstrauch syndrome
Progeria.Prognosis: Average age of death is 13 years

Psoriasis.Symptoms: Red (purple on darker skin), itchy, scaly patches of skin
Psoriasis.Causes: Genetic disease triggered by environmental factors
Psoriasis.Treatment: Steroid creams, vitamin D3 cream, ultraviolet light, Immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate

Puerperal sepsis.Other names: Puerperal fever, childbed fever, maternal sepsis, maternal infection, puerperal infections
Puerperal sepsis.Symptoms: Fever, lower abdominal pain, bad-smelling vaginal discharge
Puerperal sepsis.Risk factors: Cesarean section, premature rupture of membranes, prolonged labour, malnutrition, diabetes

Pulmonary embolism.Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chest pain, coughing up blood
Pulmonary embolism.Complications: Passing out, abnormally low blood pressure, sudden death; chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (long-term complication)
Pulmonary embolism.Risk factors: Cancer, prolonged bed rest, smoking, stroke, certain genetic conditions, estrogen-based medication, pregnancy, obesity, after surgery
Pulmonary embolism.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, D-dimer, CT pulmonary angiography, lung ventilation/perfusion scan

Ques fever.Differential diagnosis: pneumonia, influenza, brucellosis, leptospirosis, meningitis, viral hepatitis, dengue fever, malaria, other rickettsial infections

Quinsy.Symptoms: Fever, throat pain, trouble opening the mouth, change to the voice
Quinsy.Complications: Blockage of the airway, aspiration pneumonitis
Quinsy.Differential diagnosis: Retropharyngeal abscess, infectious mononucleosis, epiglottitis, cancer
Quinsy.Treatment: Remove pus, antibiotics, fluids, pain medication, steroids

Rabies.Symptoms: Fever, fear of water, confusion, excessive salivation, hallucinations, trouble sleeping, paralysis, coma
Rabies.Prevention: Rabies vaccine, animal control, rabies immunoglobulin
Rabies.Prognosis: Virtually 100% fatal after onset of symptoms

Raynaud's Phenomenon.Other names: Raynaud's, Raynaud's disease, Raynaud's phenomenon, Raynaud's syndrome
Raynaud's Phenomenon.Symptoms: An affected part turning white, then blue, then red, burning
Raynaud's Phenomenon.Duration: Up to several hours per episode
Raynaud's Phenomenon.Treatment: Avoiding cold, calcium channel blockers, iloprost

Repetitive strain injury.Other names: Cumulative trauma disorders, repetitive stress injuries, repetitive motion injuries or disorders, occupational or sports overuse syndromes
Repetitive strain injury.Specialty: Sports medicine, performing arts medicine, orthopedics
Repetitive strain injury.Symptoms: Sore wrists, aching, pulsing pain, tingling, extremity weakness
Repetitive strain injury.Prevention: Proper technique, regular rests, regular exercise

Rheumatic fever.Symptoms: Fever, multiple painful joints, involuntary muscle movements, erythema marginatum
Rheumatic fever.Complications: Rheumatic heart disease, heart failure, atrial fibrillation, infection of the valves
Rheumatic fever.Usual onset: 2–4 weeks after a streptococcal throat infection, age 5-14 years
Rheumatic fever.Causes: Autoimmune disease triggered by Streptococcus pyogenes
Rheumatic fever.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and infection history
Rheumatic fever.Prevention: Antibiotics for strep throat, improved sanitation
Rheumatic fever.Treatment: Prolonged periods of antibiotics, valve replacement surgery, valve repair

Rickets.Symptoms: Bowed legs, stunted growth, bone pain, large forehead, trouble sleeping
Rickets.Complications: Bone fractures, muscle spasms, abnormally curved spine, intellectual disability
Rickets.Causes: Diet without enough vitamin D or calcium, too little sun exposure, exclusive breastfeeding without supplementation, celiac disease, certain genetic conditions
Rickets.Differential diagnosis: Fanconi syndrome, scurvy, Lowe syndrome, osteomalacia
Rickets.Prevention: Vitamin D supplements for exclusively-breastfed babies

Rift Valley fever.Complications: Loss of sight, confusion, bleeding, liver problems
Rift Valley fever.Causes: Phlebovirus spread by an infected animal or mosquito
Rift Valley fever.Diagnostic method: Finding antibodies or the virus in the blood
Rift Valley fever.Prevention: Vaccinating animals against the disease, decreasing mosquito bites

Rocky Mountain spotted fever.Other names: Blue disease, Brazilian spotted fever, Tobia fever, new world spotted fever, tick- borne typhus fever, Sao Paulo fever
Rocky Mountain spotted fever.Differential diagnosis: Zika fever, dengue, chikungunya, Rickettsia parkeri rickettsiosis, Pacific Coast tick fever, rickettsialpox

Rubella.Symptoms: Rash, swollen lymph nodes, fever, sore throat, feeling tired
Rubella.Complications: Testicular swelling, inflammation of nerves, congenital rubella syndrome, miscarriage
Rubella.Diagnostic method: Finding the virus in the blood, throat, or urine, antibody tests

SARS.Symptoms: Fever, persistent dry cough, headache, muscle pains, difficulty breathing
SARS.Complications: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with other comorbidities that eventually leads to death
SARS.Prevention: Hand washing, cough etiquette, avoiding close contact with infected persons, avoiding travel to affected areas

SIDS.Symptoms: Death of a child less than one year of age
SIDS.Risk factors: Sleeping on the stomach or side, overheating, exposure to tobacco smoke, bed sharing
SIDS.Diagnostic method: No cause found after an investigation and autopsy
SIDS.Differential diagnosis: Infections, genetic disorders, heart problems, child abuse
SIDS.Prevention: Putting newborns on their back to sleep, pacifier, breastfeeding, immunization

Sarcoidosis.Symptoms: Depends on the organ involvedLungs: wheezing, cough, shortness of breath, chest painSkin: lumps, ulcers, discolored skinChildren: weight loss, bone pain, feeling tired
Sarcoidosis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and tissue biopsy
Sarcoidosis.Differential diagnosis: Tuberculosis, lymphoma, infectious mononucleosis, pulmonary eosinophilia

Scabies.Causes: Sarcoptes scabiei mite spread by close contact
Scabies.Risk factors: Crowded living conditions (child care facilities, group homes, prisons), lack of access to water
Scabies.Differential diagnosis: seborrheic dermatitis, dermatitis herpetiformis, pediculosis, atopic dermatitis

Scarlet fever.Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, headaches, swollen lymph nodes, characteristic rash
Scarlet fever.Prevention: Handwashing, not sharing personal items, staying away from sick people

Schizophrenia.Symptoms: Hallucinations (usually hearing voices), delusions, paranoia, confused thinking
Schizophrenia.Risk factors: Family history, cannabis use in adolescence, problems during pregnancy, childhood adversity, birth in late winter or early spring, older father, being born or raised in a city
Schizophrenia.Diagnostic method: Based on observed behavior, reported experiences, and reports of others familiar with the person
Schizophrenia.Differential diagnosis: Substance use disorder, Huntington's disease, mood disorders (bipolar disorder), autism, borderline personality disorder

Sciatica.Other names: Sciatic neuritis, sciatic neuralgia, lumbar radiculopathy, radicular leg pain
Sciatica.Symptoms: Pain going down the leg from the lower back, weakness or numbness of the affected leg
Sciatica.Complications: Loss of bowel or bladder control
Sciatica.Duration: 90% of the time less than 6 weeks
Sciatica.Causes: Spinal disc herniation, spondylolisthesis, spinal stenosis, piriformis syndrome, pelvic tumor

Scrub Typhus.Other names: Bush typhus, mite typhus, jungle typhus

Scurvy.Other names: Moeller's disease, Cheadle's disease, scorbutus, Barlow's disease, hypoascorbemia, vitamin C deficiency
Scurvy.Symptoms: Weakness, feeling tired, changes to hair, sore arms and legs, gum disease, easy bleeding
Scurvy.Risk factors: Mental disorders, unusual eating habits, homelessness, alcoholism, substance use disorder, intestinal malabsorption, dialysis, voyages at sea (historic)

Sepsis.Other names: Septicemia, blood poisoning, severe sepsis, septic shock
Sepsis.Symptoms: Fever, increased heart rate, low blood pressure, increased breathing rate, low urine output or absent or near absent urine output, severe pain, confusion
Sepsis.Complications: Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome; temporary, transient, or permanent organ damage; extra corporeal membrane oxygenation; blood filtration or dialysis
Sepsis.Usual onset: May be rapid (<3 hours) or prolonged (several days)
Sepsis.Causes: Immune response triggered by an infection
Sepsis.Risk factors: Young or old age, cancer, diabetes, major trauma, asthma, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, multiple myeloma, burns

Sexually transmitted infections (STIs).Symptoms: None, vaginal discharge, penile discharge, ulcers on or around the genitals, pelvic pain

Shaken Baby Syndrome.Other names: abusive head trauma, non accidental head injury
Shaken Baby Syndrome.Complications: Seizures, visual impairment, cerebral palsy, cognitive impairment

Shigellosis.Complications: Reactive arthritis, sepsis, seizures, hemolytic uremic syndrome

Shin splints.Other names: Medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS), soleus syndrome, tibial stress syndrome, periostitis
Shin splints.Symptoms: Pain along the inside edge of the shinbone
Shin splints.Differential diagnosis: Stress fracture, tendinitis, exertional compartment syndrome
Shin splints.Treatment: Rest with gradual return to exercise

Shingles.Symptoms: Painful rash occurring in a stripe
Shingles.Risk factors: Old age, poor immune function, having had chickenpox before 18 months of age

Sickle-cell anemia.Symptoms: Attacks of pain, anemia, swelling in the hands and feet, bacterial infections, stroke
Sickle-cell anemia.Complications: Chronic pain, stroke, aseptic bone necrosis, gallstones, leg ulcers, priapism, pulmonary hypertension, vision problems, kidney problems
Sickle-cell anemia.Treatment: Vaccination, antibiotics, high fluid intake, folic acid supplementation, pain medication, blood transfusions

Smallpox.Other names: Variola, variola vera, pox, red plague
Smallpox.Symptoms:
Early: Fever, vomiting, mouth sores
Later: Fluid filled blisters which scab over
Smallpox.Causes: Variola major, Variola minor (spread between people)
Smallpox.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and confirmed by PCR

Stevens-Johnson syndrome.Symptoms: Fever, skin blisters, skin peeling, painful skin, red eyes
Stevens-Johnson syndrome.Complications: Dehydration, sepsis, pneumonia, multiple organ failure.
Stevens-Johnson syndrome.Diagnostic method: <10% of the skin involved, skin biopsy
Stevens-Johnson syndrome.Differential diagnosis: Chickenpox, staphylococcal epidermolysis, staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, autoimmune bullous disease
Stevens-Johnson syndrome.Medication: Pain medication, antihistamines, antibiotics, corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulins
Stevens-Johnson syndrome.Frequency: 1–2 per million per year (together with TEN)

Stomach ulcers.Other names: Peptic ulcer, stomach ulcer, gastric ulcer, duodenal ulcer
Stomach ulcers.Symptoms: Heartburn, upper abdominal pain, nausea, belching, vomiting, blood in the stool, weight loss, weight gain, bloating, loss of appetite  yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes difficulty swallowing
Stomach ulcers.Complications: Bleeding, perforation, ulcer perforation, blockage of the stomach
Stomach ulcers.Causes: Helicobacter pylori bacteria, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), tobacco smoking, Crohn's disease
Stomach ulcers.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, confirmed by endoscopy or barium swallow
Stomach ulcers.Differential diagnosis: Stomach cancer, coronary heart disease, inflammation of the stomach lining, gallbladder inflammation
Stomach ulcers.Treatment: Medications, stopping NSAIDs, stopping smoking, stopping alcohol consumption
Stomach ulcers.Medication: Proton pump inhibitor, H2 blocker, antibiotics

Strep throat.Other names: Streptococcal tonsillitis, streptococcal sore throat, strep
Strep throat.Symptoms: Fever, sore throat, large lymph nodes
Strep throat.Differential diagnosis: Epiglottitis, infectious mononucleosis, Ludwig's angina, peritonsillar abscess, retropharyngeal abscess, viral pharyngitis

Stroke.Other names: Cerebrovascular accident (CVA), cerebrovascular insult (CVI), brain attack
Stroke.Symptoms: Inability to move or feel on one side of the body, problems understanding or speaking, dizziness, loss of vision to one side
Stroke.Risk factors: High blood pressure, tobacco smoking, obesity, high blood cholesterol, diabetes mellitus, previous TIA, end-stage kidney disease, atrial fibrillation
Stroke.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms with medical imaging typically used to rule out bleeding

Sub-conjunctival Haemorrhage.Symptoms: Red spot over whites of the eye, little to no pain
Sub-conjunctival Haemorrhage.Risk factors: High blood pressure, diabetes, older age
Sub-conjunctival Haemorrhage.Differential diagnosis: Open globe, retrobulbar hematoma, conjunctivitis, pterygium

Syphilis.Causes: Treponema pallidum usually spread by sex
Syphilis.Diagnostic method: Blood tests, dark field microscopy of infected fluid

Taeniasis.Types: Taenia solium (pork tapeworm), Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm), Taenia asiatica (Asian tapeworm)
Taeniasis.Risk factors: Eating contaminated undercooked pork or beef

Taeniasis/cysticercosis.Prevention: Improved sanitation, treating those with taeniasis, cooking pork well
Taeniasis/cysticercosis.Medication: Praziquantel, albendazole, corticosteroids, anti seizure medications

Tay-Sachs disease.Symptoms: Initially: Decreased ability to turn over, sit, or crawlLater: Seizures, hearing loss, inability to move
Tay-Sachs disease.Usual onset: Three to six months of age
Tay-Sachs disease.Diagnostic method: Testing blood hexosaminidase A levels, genetic testing
Tay-Sachs disease.Differential diagnosis: Sandhoff disease, Leigh syndrome, neuronal ceroid lipofuscinoses
Tay-Sachs disease.Prognosis: Death often occurs in early childhood

Tennis elbow.Symptoms: Painful and tender outer part of the elbow
Tennis elbow.Causes: Excessive use of the muscles of the back of the forearm
Tennis elbow.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms with medical imaging used to rule out other potential causes
Tennis elbow.Treatment: Changing activities, physical therapy, pain medication

Tetanus.Symptoms: fever, cramped-up jaw, Muscle spasms, headache, seizures, sweating, and trouble swallowing
Tetanus.Treatment: Tetanus immune globulin, muscle relaxants, mechanical ventilation

Thalassaemia.Symptoms: Feeling tired, pale skin, enlarged spleen, yellowish skin, dark urine
Thalassaemia.Treatment: Blood transfusions, iron chelation, folic acid

Tinnitus.Symptoms: Hearing sound when no external sound is present
Tinnitus.Causes: Noise-induced hearing loss, ear infections, disease of the heart or blood vessels, Ménière's disease, brain tumors, inner ear tumors, emotional stress, traumatic brain injury, excessive earwax
Tinnitus.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, audiogram, neurological exam

Tonsillitis.Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, enlargement of the tonsils, trouble swallowing, large lymph nodes around the neck
Tonsillitis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, throat swab, rapid strep test

Toxic shock syndrome.Symptoms: Fever, rash, skin peeling, low blood pressure
Toxic shock syndrome.Risk factors: Very absorbent tampons, skin lesions in young children
Toxic shock syndrome.Differential diagnosis: Septic shock, Kawasaki's disease, Stevens–Johnson syndrome, scarlet fever
Toxic shock syndrome.Treatment: Antibiotics, incision and drainage of any abscesses, intravenous immunoglobulin

Trachoma.Other names: Granular conjunctivitis, blinding trachoma, Egyptian ophthalmia
Trachoma.Risk factors: Crowded living conditions, not enough clean water and toilets

Trichinosis.Symptoms: Initially: diarrhea, abdominal pain, vomitingLater: swelling of the face, inflammation of the whites of the eyes, fever, muscle pains, rash
Trichinosis.Complications: Inflammation of heart muscle, inflammation of the lungs
Trichinosis.Diagnostic method: Antibodies in the blood, larvae on tissue biopsy

Trichomoniasis.Symptoms: Itching in the genital area, bad smelling thin vaginal discharge, burning with urination, pain with sex
Trichomoniasis.Diagnostic method: Finding the parasite in vaginal fluid, microbial culture, testing for the parasites DNA
Trichomoniasis.Prevention: Not having sex, using condoms, not douching

Tuberculosis.Other names: Phthisis, phthisis pulmonalis, consumption, great white plague
Tuberculosis.Symptoms: Chronic cough, fever, cough with bloody mucus, weight loss
Tuberculosis.Prevention: Screening those at high risk, treatment of those infected, vaccination with bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG)

Tularemia.Other names: Tularaemia, Pahvant Valley plague, rabbit fever, deer fly fever, Ohara's fever
Tularemia.Symptoms: Fever, skin ulcer, large lymph nodes
Tularemia.Causes: Francisella tularensis (spread by ticks, deer flies, contact with infected animals)
Tularemia.Prevention: Insect repellent, wearing long pants, rapidly removing ticks, not disturbing dead animals

Turners Syndrome.Other names: Ullrich–Turner syndrome, Bonnevie–Ullrich–Turner syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis; 45X, 45X0
Turners Syndrome.Symptoms: Webbed neck, short stature, swollen hands and feet
Turners Syndrome.Complications: Heart defects, diabetes, low thyroid hormone
Turners Syndrome.Medication: Human growth hormone, estrogen replacement therapy

Urticaria.Causes: Following an infection, result of an allergic reaction

Varicose Veins.Symptoms: None, fullness, pain in the area
Varicose Veins.Risk factors: Obesity, not enough exercise, leg trauma, family history, pregnancy

Vasovagal syncope.Symptoms: Loss of consciousness before which there may be sweating, decreased ability to see, ringing in the ears
Vasovagal syncope.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms after ruling out other possible causes
Vasovagal syncope.Treatment: Avoiding triggers, drinking sufficient fluids, exercise, cardiac pacemaker

Vitamin B12 Deficiency.Symptoms: Vary with degree – mild deficiency: fatigue, and anemia; moderate: megaloblastic anemia with glossitis, some neurological effects; severe deficiency: more defined neurological symptoms such as pins and needles sensations, severe depression, exercise intolerance
Vitamin B12 Deficiency.Complications: Megaloblastic anemia, irreversible damage to the brain and nervous system
Vitamin B12 Deficiency.Causes: Poor absorption, decreased intake, increased requirements
Vitamin B12 Deficiency.Risk factors: Pernicious anemia, genetic disorders, age, vegans, atrophic gastritis and other chronic gastrointestinal diseases
Vitamin B12 Deficiency.Diagnostic method: Blood levels below 130–180 pmol/L (180–250 pg/mL) in adults
Vitamin B12 Deficiency.Prevention: Supplementation in those at high risk

Warts.Differential diagnosis: Callus, seborrheic keratosis, squamous cell carcinoma
Warts.Prevention: Avoiding skin contact with infected individual, not walking barefoot in public areas
Warts.Treatment: Salicylic acid, cryotherapy, chemo based Fluorouracil or Bleomycin

Yaws.Other names: Frambesia tropica, thymosis, polypapilloma tropicum, non-venereal endemic syphilis, parangi and paru (Malay), bouba (Spanish), frambösie, pian (French), frambesia (German), bakataw (Maguindanaoan)
Yaws.Symptoms: Hard swelling of the skin, ulcer, joint and bone pain
Yaws.Causes: Treponema pallidum pertenue spread by direct contact
Yaws.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, blood antibody tests, polymerase chain reaction

Yellow Fever.Other names: Yellow jack, yellow plague, bronze john
Yellow Fever.Symptoms: Fever, chills, muscle pain, headache, yellow skin
Yellow Fever.Causes: Yellow fever virus spread by mosquitoes

Zika virus disease.Other names: Zika virus disease, Zika, Zika virus infection
Zika virus disease.Symptoms: Fever, red eyes, joint pain, headache, maculopapular rash, Sometimes none
Zika virus disease.Complications: Guillain–Barré syndrome, during pregnancy can cause microcephaly in the baby
Zika virus disease.Causes: Zika virus mainly spread by mosquitoes, can also be sexually transmitted
Zika virus disease.Diagnostic method: Testing blood, urine, or saliva for viral RNA or blood for antibodies
Zika virus disease.Treatment: Supportive care, Generally not needed in mild cases

lactose intolerance.Other names: Lactase deficiency, hypolactasia, alactasia, lactose challenged
lactose intolerance.Symptoms: Abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, flatulence, nausea
lactose intolerance.Complications: Does not cause damage to the GI tract
lactose intolerance.Causes: Decreased ability to digest lactose (genetic, small intestine injury)
lactose intolerance.Differential diagnosis: Irritable bowel syndrome, celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, milk allergy
lactose intolerance.Treatment: Decreasing lactose in the diet, lactase supplements, treat the underlying cause
lactose intolerance.Frequency: ~65% of people (less common in Northern Europeans)
